_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Company:  South Central Coop
Contact:  Len Kohlman
Phone:  641-534-3121

Facility Policy
South Central Coop is a full service farm supply company with the greatest risk of release coming from our anhydrous ammonia storage tanks.  We are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Decatur County LEPC, and other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.

Facility Information
The primary activity of this facility is to store and distribute anhydrous ammonia in storage and nurse tanks, for  the application and fertilization of agronomic crops.

Accidental Release Prevention Program
The facility has been reviewed for general compliance with provision of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1".  Published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI), and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The ANSI Standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Adminisrative Code Part 21 - Chapter 42-Rule 43.6 (200).  "Standard for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The OSHA Standard is referenced in the registration form Section 8:3b.  Additional accidental release prevention measures we utilize range from employee training to equipment maintenance.  We have excess flow valves, back check valves, and pressure relief valves on our ammonia system.  We also have gauges to tell us when these tanks are full to prevent the over filling of these tanks which in turn create an accidental release.

Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia or personal injuries in the last five years.  To my knowledge there has been no off-site damage resulting in death, injury, evacuation, property damage, or environ

mental impact.

Emergency Action Plan
Our Emergency Response Program consists of a written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38.  We also follow the Iowa Fertilizer Rule Standards and provide state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).  We will notify the local authorities as well as the LEPC if a release occurs.  Our role as the company will be to secure the area until local authorities arrive and assist them in any way possible.

Safety improvements are an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the condtions of the facility.  We have implemented new requirements such as locking storage tanks and placing vehicle barriers around the storage tanks and plumbing.  We also have tested the underground pipe system in August of 2008.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations at this time.
